Award.AwardTitle: Microbial Iron Acquisition: Investigations of Amphiphilic Siderophores
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) program supports work by Professor Alison Butler at the University of California, Santa Barbara to carry out fundamental studies on the process of iron acquisition by bacteria that is mediated by siderophores. Nearly all bacteria require iron to grow. Siderophores are low molecular mass chelating ligands produced by bacteria that coordinate Fe(III) with very high affinity and facilitate iron uptake by the bacterium. Marine bacteria often produce suites of amphiphilic siderophores that vary in the nature of the fatty acid tail. The interactions of the amphiphilic siderophores, their self-assembled structures and the bacteria will be probed to investigate whether the amphiphilic character of these siderophores confers a distinct molecular advantage for microbial iron acquisition.

This project supports the education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in a highly interdisciplinary research project in a manner that will serve to broaden and deepen the level of research training. Some marine bacteria grow on petroleum hydrocarbons as their sole source of carbon and energy; yet before bacteria can begin to oxidize hydrocarbons, they must first acquire iron for growth and then for assimilation into the key enzymes. Thus understanding how oil-degrading bacteria acquire the essential nutrient, iron, would benefit efforts to enhance microbial hydrocarbon oxidation of environmental concern.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The majority of bacteria require iron to grow; yet iron is often present in the environment as insoluble iron oxide materials. To facilitate iron uptake, bacteria often secrete small molecules to solubilize and sequester iron.  These molecules, called siderophores, are low molecular weight chelating ligands that coordinate Fe(III) with very high affinity.  A newly recognized distinguishing characteristic of siderophores produced by marine bacteria is the prevalence of suites of amphiphilic siderophores, one family of which is based on a common Fe(III)-coordinating head group and appended by one of a series of fatty acid tails. 

In terms of the intellectual merit, the major goals of the research were to isolate and characterize siderophores produced by bacteria in association with oil (e.g., Gulf of Mexico after the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, natural oil seepage sites), as well as from other bacterial isolates, and to investigate reactivity of the amphiphilic siderophores particularly with respect to acyl hydrolysis. Iron is known to be a limiting nutrient in oil-polluted waters, thus the finding may be beneficial in designing future oil remediation strategies.  Many oil-associated bacteria were found to produce suites of amphiphilic siderophores, which may facilitate contact with petroleum and promote growth on aliphatic hydrocarbon oxidation.  As the research progressed we investigated selected non marine isolates based on genomic predictions for acylated siderophores. The isolation of amphiphilic siderophores from other sources revealed a wider spread existence of these siderophores, than previously recognized, including the amphi-enterbactins from Vibrio harveyi, a bacterium widely used to study the process of quorum sensing.

In terms of the broader impact activities, the grant provided multidisciplinary training to the graduate students and undergraduates in my laboratory, and international exposure through extended visits of two students to my laboratory. Ten graduate students, two rotation students and five undergraduates carried out research on this project. In outreach activities, I was faculty advisor to the 2012 Apprentice Researcher Program at UCSB for 16 diverse high school students from Santa Barbara and Ventura counties carrying out summer research projects with a graduate student mentor in the sciences and engineering. I worked with each student on understanding the science in their projects, as well as their written and oral presentations.  I was the Acting Director of the 2012 Research Mentorship Program through UCSB Summer Sessions for a diverse group of 79 US and International high school students carrying out research projects (most in science & engineering), overseeing their presentations and communications. I became the advisor to 10 high school students selected from RMP for a 2012 California Institution of Regenerative Medicine (CIRM) Creativity Award; they presented posters at Stanford University with all 60 2012 CIRM Creativity Awardees in California.  I arranged for the UCSB CIRM high school students to present at the American Junior Academy of Science (AJAS) Conference held with the Annual AAAS meeting in Boston in February 2013. I worked with these students on their oral and poster presentations. I moderated the AJAS oral presentations session on Chemistry & Biochemistry at the AJAS/AAAS meeting.   I also began a term on the External Advisory Committee of the NSF/NIH Minority Opportunities in Research (MORE) Program at California State University, Los Angeles in 2011.
